experience-arashiyama-monkeys.name: Arashiyama Monkey Park Iwatayama

text.text:
What a great experience visiting the monkeys! The park is located up a hill and takes about 20‚Äì30 minutes to reach on foot, but the walk is well worth it. Once you arrive, you‚Äôre greeted with breathtaking panoramic views of the city easily one of the best vantage points in Kyoto.

The monkeys roam freely in a natural environment, and it was so fun (and safe!) to watch them up close. For just 100 yen, you can buy food and feed them from inside a small hut, which makes for an amazing photo opportunity.

The staff were friendly, and the park is well maintained. A perfect mix of nature, animals, and incredible views. Highly recommended if you‚Äôre in Kyoto!

text.text: If you‚Äôre looking for something fun and unique to do while in Kyoto, this is definitely it! It‚Äôs about a 20 - 30 minute uphill walk to get to the top of the mountain where the monkey park is, so make sure to wear good shoes. It‚Äôs 800¬• to enter and no reservations needed, and if you want to feed them with the food they provide, it‚Äôs a small cost (I can‚Äôt remember how much but it‚Äôs cheap). The monkeys are adorable and they‚Äôre everywhere! Be sure to only admire them from afar, don‚Äôt try to pet them because they‚Äôre wild animals. Aside from the monkeys there‚Äôs also wonderful views of Kyoto down below. We comfortably spent about 2 - 2.5 hours here including the hikes.

text.text: Arashiyama Monkey Park was an adventurous and exciting experience‚Äî YOU are in the monkeys‚Äô territory so be respectful of that. It cost 800 yen per adult (children are 400 yen). Be prepared to walk a steep hike so make sure to wear your comfiest walking/hiking shoes‚Äî I can‚Äôt say it enough, it‚Äôs very steep going up the mountain. I went during peak summer heat in mid July, so if you go around that time, make sure to take a cooling neck towel, fan, UV umbrella, water, light clothing, whatever makes you more tolerant to the heat. Respect the monkeys, don‚Äôt get in their face and if you want to take a picture don‚Äôt get too close because some may be more patient but others will not like it! The monkeys love to hang around and especially LOVE being fed. Make sure to buy the food that the staff sells (sliced bananas & peanuts), the monkeys will love you for it! For once, the humans are in cages while the monkeys roam free üêí I loved it here!

text.text:
Arashiyama Monkey Park is a fun and unique experience that‚Äôs worth the short hike! After a 15‚Äì20 minute uphill walk, you‚Äôre rewarded with incredible panoramic views of Kyoto and the chance to see wild monkeys roaming freely in their natural habitat.

The monkeys are used to people and you can even feed them (from inside a protected enclosure). It‚Äôs a cool mix of nature, wildlife, and sightseeing all in one spot.

Bring comfortable shoes and some water for the hike, but the view and the monkeys make it totally worth it. A great stop if you‚Äôre exploring the Arashiyama area!

It's really worth of visit. You need approx 3-4 hours to enjoy this castle.

text.text:
Great experience!

We booked a local guide (local teacher) and it was an amazing experience to get to this spiritual place, walk up the castle and get an understanding of the importance and the history of the castle and location.

Built in 1601-1609 with the target to support Edo and to limit influence from Osaka to west Japan has a lot of important historic background and worth a trip.

The main two wooden pillars have been around 300 years old (before cutting) and then served 400 years as the main parts of the construction. One had to be replaced around 1950 and you will find the details on how much work was spent to make this happen and to stabilize the full construction.

When taking the tour (and guide) you will get the clear explanation how this castle was setup to put a stake into the ground and how to defend it in every situation. Lots of engineering craftmanship to visit and details show how much time and energy was spent wisely here.

The shrine on the top floor and the history behind it plus the families living there gives a good view on what might have happened here centuries ago.

The view from the guarden onto the castle / main tower is just outstanding. Osaka castle was a very inspiring place, too, but this one was truly exceptional. Don't rush through and take your time (at least 2,5h) to learn and understand the concepts.

You will be rewarded with a deeper understanding of history and warcraftship of this period of time. Worth the time and money.

As it was quite hot today, drink enough water to stay healthy. IN case you face trouble, don't worry, the owner organized very good medical support inside / outside the castle tour.

Inside the main building are not much furniture, as it was mainly a tower which was used as storage for weapons and armory. When looking for more weapons / clothing / armor you should better visit an according museum.

text.text: Simply put, an amazing place to visit. Beyond the gorgeous looks and the natural exhibits throughout the premises, the park transmits a message that should resonate with us all - war is horrible in all possible ways, peace is what should unite us all and nuclear weapons should not ever be used again, it's hard not to feel emotional walking throughout it. The park has many monuments worth visiting if you're in Hiroshima, and it's situated just across the river from the famous atomic dome. On the North side of the park you'll also find the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum, which contains an amazing permanent exhibition that highlights the devastating consequences the use of the atomic bomb has had on the city. Worth visiting!

Absolutely stunning spot, especially when the tide is high and the shrine appears to float on the water. The atmosphere is peaceful and the location is iconic.
Just a heads-up: be sure to check the tide schedule before you go, as high tide offers the most beautiful scenery. It can also get quite crowded at times, there were up to 30 people lining up just to take a photo in front of the famous torii gate.
Still, totally worth the visit!

text.text:
One of our favourite places we visited in our 4 weeks in Japan.
It poured with rain most of the day, but was atmospheric with mist over the mountains. Once it cleared up and the tide went out, it was majestic.
The deer are amazing and wonder around Just as the humans do. You will be sure to make some deer friends.
Get yourself a reusable drink cup from the Gebura bar when you arrive and enjoy refills all day for ¬£1.
Absolutely must do trip, even if only for a day, if you are near Hiroshima. Tram 2 takes you all the way from Hiroshima station to the boat port for a few pounds.

text.text:
From the moment I stepped off the ferry, I was greeted by the delightful sight of the island‚Äôs deer, eager for a nibble.
The serenity of the surroundings was striking, and the atmosphere was truly calming.
A short walk just offshore leads to the magnificent Great Torii Gate, partially submerged at high tide, which marks the entrance to the historic Itsukushima Shrine, originally established in the 12th century.
Exploring the village was equally enjoyable, with a myriad of delightful eateries and charming spots to relax.
I found the local cuisine to be remarkable, adding to the overall experience.
I highly recommend visiting Itsukushima Island for anyone seeking a peaceful escape while immersing themselves in rich cultural heritage.

experience-sapporo-snow-festival.name: Odori Park

text.text:
Odori Park is a must-visit destination in Sapporo, offering a perfect blend of nature, culture, and city life. Stretching over 1.5 kilometers, the park divides the city into north and south, serving as a refreshing green space amidst Sapporo's urban landscape.

During my visit, I was struck by the park's meticulously landscaped gardens, vibrant flower displays, and iconic landmarks like the Sapporo TV Tower. The park is especially lively during events like the Sapporo Snow Festival and the summer beer garden, making it a dynamic spot for both locals and tourists.

Whether you're strolling through the pathways, relaxing on a bench, or enjoying the seasonal festivals, Odori Park provides a peaceful yet vibrant atmosphere. Its central location, accessibility, and diverse attractions make it a highlight of any trip to Sapporo.

text.text:
üå≥ Odori Park ‚Äì Sapporo‚Äôs Chillest Backyard üå∏

Smack in the center of Sapporo, Odori Park stretches over a dozen blocks and feels like the city just exhaled. It‚Äôs not your typical ‚Äúbig attraction,‚Äù but that‚Äôs kind of what makes it great. It‚Äôs where locals walk their dogs, kids chase pigeons, and travelers like us take a breath between ramen bowls and sightseeing stops.

The park runs east to west, carving a green path right through downtown. Depending on when you visit, you might stumble into a full-blown festival, a beer garden, an ice sculpture competition, or‚Ä¶ nothing at all‚Äîand somehow, that‚Äôs just as nice. In summer, it‚Äôs all fountains and flowerbeds; in winter, it‚Äôs a snow-covered wonderland.

It‚Äôs not flashy, but it‚Äôs the kind of place that grounds you in the city. Sit on a bench, grab a soft serve or hot corn from a stall, and just watch life go by.

üí° Pro tip: Head to Sapporo TV Tower on the eastern end for a great aerial view of the park. And if you‚Äôre here during a festival‚Äîlike the Snow Festival or the Summer Beer Garden‚Äîit goes from peaceful park to full-on party real fast.

text.text:
DiverCity Tokyo Plaza offers a fantastic blend of shopping, dining, and entertainment. The highlight is the life-size Unicorn Gundam statue that transforms and lights up at scheduled times truly a sight to behold. Inside, you'll find a diverse range of stores, from fashion boutiques to the Gundam Base Tokyo, perfect for fans and collectors.

The food court is spacious and offers a variety of delicious options to suit all tastes. Whether you're into shopping, anime, or just looking for a fun place to explore, DiverCity has something for everyone. Easily accessible via public transport, it's a great destination for both tourists and locals.

text.text:
DiverCity Tokyo Plaza („ÉÄ„Ç§„Éê„Éº„Ç∑„ÉÜ„Ç£Êù±‰∫¨ „Éó„É©„Ç∂) is a solid, well-rounded shopping mall made even better by its surroundings in scenic Odaiba. With 8 floors of shops, restaurants, and family-friendly entertainment, it‚Äôs a nice stop whether you‚Äôre there to shop, sightsee, or take in a Gundam or two. 4/5 ‚Äì A worthwhile destination, especially when paired with the rest of Odaiba‚Äôs offerings.

Full Review:
There are malls‚Äîand then there are malls that become part of a larger experience. DiverCity Tokyo Plaza („ÉÄ„Ç§„Éê„Éº„Ç∑„ÉÜ„Ç£Êù±‰∫¨ „Éó„É©„Ç∂) is very much the latter.

Located in the ever-fascinating Odaiba district, this shopping center isn‚Äôt just a place to browse Uniqlo or grab lunch‚Äîit‚Äôs a stepping stone in a day full of discovery. Nestled right next to AquaCity, which boasts a cinema and waterfront views complete with a replica Statue of Liberty, DiverCity plays an important role in the area‚Äôs ecosystem of entertainment, retail, and leisure.

The mall itself spans eight levels, with a balanced mix of international and Japanese fashion brands, casual eateries, proper restaurants, and even a dedicated entertainment floor.

Beyond the shops and food, there‚Äôs a life-sized Unicorn Gundam statue standing guard outside‚Äîa tourist magnet and the very definition of ‚ÄúInstagrammable.‚Äù Whether you're into anime or not, it adds a distinctly unique flair and a touch of fun to the entire experience. It‚Äôs hard not to admire the juxtaposition of sleek retail interiors with full-on mecha grandeur just outside the doors.

Now, is DiverCity the most luxurious mall you‚Äôll visit in Tokyo? Not quite. It doesn‚Äôt aim for that. It‚Äôs clean, modern, and efficiently designed, with wide walkways and enough signage (in English too) to guide even the most directionally challenged tourists. It‚Äôs more practical destination hub than fashion mecca‚Äîbut that‚Äôs not a bad thing.

Final Verdict: 4/5
DiverCity Tokyo Plaza doesn‚Äôt try to outshine Tokyo‚Äôs more elite shopping malls, but it doesn‚Äôt need to. Its strength lies in its location, balance, and ability to be both a tourist-friendly stop and a local haunt. Combine it with a stroll by the waterfront, a few photos with the Gundam, and a good meal, and you‚Äôve got yourself a pretty enjoyable outing in Odaiba.

text.text:
A museum where various exhibitions are held for a limited time.

You'll probably find it interesting if you go, but it depends on your preferences.

On the day when everyday medical equipment was on display, it was very interesting to talk to salesmen and developers about the products on sale and those under development.

Recently, on the day of the e-sports exhibition, you can actually play games, there are game controllers that you can tap with your feet, and you can collect experience stamps in the venue and get prizes.

In the Birdman Contest exhibition, several actual aircraft were displayed in the air all over the venue, and the simulator game where you pedal to read the wind and keep flying was also interesting.

text.text:
A moment to feel the soul-filled traces of the brush.

I was able to see the works of many different calligraphers at once, and the individuality and thoughts of each artist were clearly conveyed through their brushstrokes.
Sometimes powerful, sometimes delicate, it was as if the characters had been breathed into life.
I was impressed by how broad the range of expression can be within the same art of calligraphy.

It was a rare space where I could truly feel the soul that was put into each and every character.

Beautiful park.
Well kept and clean.

originalText.text:

text.text: Simply put, an amazing place to visit. Beyond the gorgeous looks and the natural exhibits throughout the premises, the park transmits a message that should resonate with us all - war is horrible in all possible ways, peace is what should unite us all and nuclear weapons should not ever be used again, it's hard not to feel emotional walking throughout it. The park has many monuments worth visiting if you're in Hiroshima, and it's situated just across the river from the famous atomic dome. On the North side of the park you'll also find the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum, which contains an amazing permanent exhibition that highlights the devastating consequences the use of the atomic bomb has had on the city. Worth visiting!

Probably the most touristic shrine in Kyoto but for a reason. Extremely beautiful, especially the Torii Gates.

There's a long and a short hike path through hundreds of gates and the mountain view is great as well.

I came once before in 2018 and it was less touristy, it's become very full, but that's the price to pay for such a nice shrine. I got very lucky with the last photo. But they are also maintaining the shrine more easily because of this.

Please be respectful if you visit.

text.text:
After quite a long walk through the scenic castle grounds, we finally arrived at Osaka Castle. It was an incredibly hot day, and to our surprise, there was a massive line stretching out in front of the entrance, it ended up being around a 50 minute wait. Thankfully, once inside, it was much cooler and more comfortable to explore.

Each floor of the castle features well-presented exhibits detailing the rich history of the castle and Osaka itself. From ancient samurai armour and weapons to historical timelines and models, there‚Äôs a lot to absorb. The elevator makes it easier to reach the top floors if you want to avoid the many steps.

At the top, we were rewarded with a panoramic 360-degree view over Osaka from the observation deck. It wasn‚Äôt too crowded up there either, likely because many people were avoiding the heat. The view alone made the climb worthwhile.

If you're planning to visit during summer or warmer days, definitely bring some water and maybe an umbrella or hat. There‚Äôs minimal shade in the queue area, so come prepared.

Osaka Castle is absolutely worth visiting, not just for its impressive structure, but also for the cultural insights and beautiful surroundings.

The illuminated castle within the peaceful surroundings felt almost magical.
For us, the evening view was even more enjoyable than a daytime visit.

text.text:
Osaka castle is a must visit for those who visit Osaka city. One of the large castle located in a big park. Atleast 15-20 mins walk inside the park till the castle from nearby JR stations.

There is a ticket counter at the entrance of the castle, costs 1200 JPY for adult. It took about 15 minutes in the queue to reach the ticket counter on a weekday. I guess weekend will have more crowd and more time better to buy online ticket. There was no queue for the entry for online tickets.

Castle is large, there are eight levels need to climb. The steps lift facility is available for the needy, which flower covers lot of information about history. It is air condition inside so was comfortable. The view from the top floor is beautiful. There is a 360¬∞ balcony from which you can have a view of Osaka city.

There are some convenient stores inside the park if you want to have some quick bites or beverages.

text.text: Tokyo Tower is a must-visit, especially during sunset. I highly recommend getting tickets for the Top Deck it offers a higher vantage point and a broader panoramic view than the Main Deck, which is still great on its own. The ticket prices are quite reasonable considering the experience. Staff members are friendly, welcoming, and always ready to guide you with a smile. Sunset time can get a bit crowded, but you'll still be able to enjoy the full 360¬∞ views without trouble. It's a peaceful yet breathtaking way to end the day in Tokyo.

text.text:
I had been looking forward to visiting Tokyo Tower, especially at night, having seen so many beautiful photos of the city lights stretching endlessly into the horizon. Seeing it in person absolutely lived up to expectations. The view from the Main Deck at 150 metres was stunning, with a full panoramic scene of Tokyo's sparkling skyline. I stayed up there for around 40 minutes taking in the sights and snapping photos from multiple angles.

Tokyo Tower stands at 333 metres tall and was inspired by the Eiffel Tower in Paris, though it‚Äôs slightly taller. Built in 1958, it originally served as a television broadcasting antenna and remains one of the city‚Äôs iconic landmarks. Its red-and-white design stands out beautifully, especially when lit up at night.

The atmosphere on the observation deck was relaxed, and there was plenty of room to enjoy the views without feeling crowded. The night lighting changes seasonally, which adds something a little different if you visit at various times of year. You can also explore souvenir shops, grab a drink, or check out the FootTown building underneath with its mini attractions and eateries.

If you're planning a trip to Tokyo, I‚Äôd definitely recommend adding this to your evening plans. It‚Äôs especially ideal for photographers and anyone wanting a breathtaking, elevated view of the city.

Tokyo Tower by Night ‚Äî Simply Magical!

I visited Tokyo Tower in the evening around 8:30pm, and the night view of the city was absolutely breathtaking. Seeing Tokyo illuminated from above ‚Äî with endless lights stretching in every direction ‚Äî was a moment I‚Äôll never forget.

The atmosphere at night is calm and romantic, and the tower itself looks stunning all lit up. The observation deck offers incredible panoramic views, and everything is well-organized and easy to access.

Whether you're into photography, architecture, or just want a memorable view of Tokyo, a nighttime visit to Tokyo Tower is an absolute must. Highly recommended!

Tokyo Tower is a must-visit if you're in the city. It‚Äôs 333 meters tall and gives amazing views of Tokyo. The main observation deck is great, but the top deck tour is worth it if you want the full experience.
The tower lights up beautifully at night and feels like a mix of old-school charm and modern vibes. It‚Äôs easy to reach, has cafes and souvenir shops, and the nearby Zojoji Temple makes the area even more scenic.
Perfect for sunset views, photos, or just soaking in the Tokyo skyline.
